title: RBA meets, but is unlikely to budge on interest rates | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The ASX 200 finished trading with a small gain, largely thanks to Westpac announcing a $7 billion full-year profit and the sale of its RAMS mortgage business for $21.4 billion. Economic news ahead of tomorrow's RBA rates decision was mixed with building approvals jumping and solid household spending, while there were worrying jobs and inflation data. title: Police investigate alleged kidnapping of Sydney developer's brother, George Ayoub | ABC NEWS
description: NSW Police are investigating claims a 28-year-old has been freed by gangland kidnappers after his family paid a $1m ransom. It is alleged George Ayoub, the brother of a Sydney property developer, was abducted outside his Belfield home. Three people have been charged with kidnapping offences. title: Optus held 11 crisis meetings before telling government about triple-0 deaths | ABC NEWS
description: Optus waited almost a day before it told the public that its triple-0 outage caused three deaths, while executives held several meetings and prepared talking points. Chief executive Stephen Rue told a Senate inquiry he was "deeply sorry" about the outage but defended his own actions and resisted calls to resign. Political reporter Evelyn Manfield has the story. title: Liberals shifting towards dumping net-zero climate target | ABC NEWS
description: The Liberal Party is considering ditching its commitment to net zero and following the Nationals in abandoning the 2050 climate target. Moderate members argue this is not a viable option.  A joint Coalition meeting is set for tomorrow, but a final decision from the Liberals is not expected this week. title: Suspected meteor event across the skies of Victoria's Gippsland region | ABC NEWS
description: Gippsland residents have reported hearing a sonic boom that shook their houses as a suspected meteor was sighted over Victoria's east. Planetary geologists have described the event as rare and are urgently trying to track down the impact site. title: Power disconnections all too common among remote First Nations communities | ABC NEWS
description: Thousands of First Nations households are struggling to keep their food, medicine, and homes cool this summer. A new report shows that people with prepaid smart meters lose power more than 30 times a year when their credit runs out.  This problem often affects elderly individuals on low incomes, who must travel long distances to recharge their power. title: Maternal healthcare has become 'a dangerous lottery' in the NT | ABC NEWS
description: Northern Territory mothers have spoken out at a maternal health forum about what they say are gaps in the NT's maternal health system. Staffing shortages at an under-resourced Royal Darwin Hospital and a lack of birthing options, including private obstetric care after the recent closure of Darwin's private maternity ward, were among the issues raised. By Felicity James for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Disability employers calling for clear path forward after Bedford collapse I ABC NEWS
description: Disability employment has been described as a sector in crisis.  In South Australia, the financial collapse of Bedford Group affected thousands of people living with a disability who seek meaningful work.  The federal government says it's providing $45m for support programs, but advocates say there's a need for a clearer way forward. title: Housing price surge from ‘perfect storm’ of policy and market conditions | ABC NEWS
description: Home values are rising at their fastest rate in two years, with a 1.1 per cent increase last month and an annual growth rate exceeding 6 per cent.  Brendan Coates from the Grattan Institute attributes this surge to a combination of housing policies and market conditions. title: Australia 'playing both sides' of critical minerals trade with US and China | ABC NEWS
description: Australia is the world's biggest producer of zirconium, a critical mineral used in everything from bathroom tiles to hypersonic missiles. As the threat of conflict looms over the Indo-Pacific, a Four Corners investigation has found two Australian companies are supplying tonnes of zirconium to China. title: Trump threatens to send US troops to Nigeria over Christian killings | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Nigeria has responded to US president Donald Trump's threats to take military action in the country to stop what he calls the killing of large numbers of Christians. An advisor to the Nigerian president has welcomed any US help in fighting Islamist insurgents as long as the country's territorial integrity is respected. title: End of an era for Perth Zoo as last elephant moves to Adelaide park | ABC News
description: Perth Zoo is now without elephants, after its last one was this morning placed onto the back of a truck to begin a two day journey across the Nullarbor to Adelaide's Monarto Safari Park. title: At least 20 dead, hundreds injured after 6.3 quake rocks northern Afghanistan | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The death toll from a powerful earthquake that's hit northern Afghanistan in the early hours of the morning has risen to at least 20 while hundreds have been injured. title: Can Trump counter years of "inefficient" action against Nigeria's insurgents? | The World | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump is threatening Nigeria with potential military action, accusing the country's government of enabling the religious persecution of Christians. The Nigerian president has pushed back against the claims, reaffirming the nation's "constitutional guarantees to protect citizens of all faiths", while a spokesperson says it welcomes US assistance in fighting extremist groups like Boko Haram. Nigerian human rights lawyer Ayodele Sogunro tells The World while Christians have been killed in the country, they are not being specifically targeted because they are Christian. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad.
